Event: ...lost my job, moved out of apartment, live with mom, no friends, struggling with self-confidence, feeling hopeless and considering suicide.
Post:
"I'm such a failure. I lost my job, moved out of my apartment, and now I'm living with my mom. I don't have any friends and I'm struggling with self-confidence. I feel hopeless and I'm even considering suicide."

This post attributes the negative events in the person's life to their own personal failings, using words like "failure" and "hopeless" to emphasize the stable attributional style. It also implies that the person's current situation is a reflection of their inherent worthlessness, rather than a temporary setback or a result of external circumstances.

Event: The individual wants to be dead.

It is an example of a stable attributional style because it suggests that the cause of the individual's desire to die is a long-lasting and inherent aspect of their personality, rather than a temporary or external factor.

The main event in this text is the individual's feelings of inadequacy and distress, as well as their isolation and loneliness. The event is described as "I always second guess everything. This event is unambiguously negative from the individual's point of view, as it interferes with their ability to enjoy life and feel confident in themselves. The event occurs in the present and hypothetical future, as the individual expresses concerns about how they will feel in different situations.
Post:
"I always second guess everything. It's gotten to the point where I compare myself to my colleagues and friends and their successes and motivations. I feel like I'm just not good enough, no matter how hard I try. I'm constantly questioning my own abilities and feel like a failure. I'm afraid that this feeling of inadequacy is going to follow me for the rest of my life."

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the individual's negative feelings and self-doubt to their own inherent flaws and shortcomings, rather than to external circumstances or temporary factors. The use of phrases like "I'm just not good enough" and "I'm constantly questioning my own abilities" suggests that the individual believes that their negative experiences are due to stable, chronic factors within themselves, rather than to specific situations or external triggers.

Event: Downloading a habit tracking app and using it to monitor and improve self-care habits.
Post:
"I've been using a habit tracking app to monitor and improve my self-care habits, and it's been a game changer for me. I've been able to stay on top of my routine and make healthy changes that have had a positive impact on my life. They are implying that they have a natural talent for organization and self-care, and that this has helped them to achieve their goals. This is an example of a stable attributional style because it implies that the individual's success is due to their own stable characteristics, rather than temporary or external factors.
